articleContent.title: Chord: 11th in A# (Shape: A)
articleContent.content:
# A#11 Chord

The A#11 chord, often shaped as an A chord, adds a unique color to a progression. This chord features the notes A#, E#, B#, F, and C. The A#11 chord is sometimes used to add tension and an unpredictable edge to a song due to the dissonance it creates within the harmony.

## Notes and Intervals
- A# (Root)
- E# (F)
- B# (C)
- F (11th)
- C (5th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The A#11 chord is commonly found in genres like jazz and R&B where musicians use its rich and jazzy sound to create tension and interest in their compositions. When used in these genres, the A#11 chord adds a sense of sophistication and depth to the music, making it feel complex and intriguing.

## Songs Featuring A#11 Chord
1. "**So What**" by Miles Davis - This jazz classic features the A#11 chord prominently in its chord progressions, adding to the modal jazz feel of the song.
2. "**Don't Know Why**" by Norah Jones - In this soulful ballad, the A#11 chord is used to create a melancholic and introspective mood.
3. "**I Heard It Through the Grapevine**" by Marvin Gaye - This Motown hit uses the A#11 chord to add a touch of tension and drama to its funky groove.
